context: Their findings indicated that the organo-clay complex is a more effective sorption medium than clay alone. Humic acid-coated aluminum oxide also has been evaluated. Peterson et al. (1988) found that trichloroethylene (TCE) sorption onto coated particles was consistent with that in whole soils, i.e., diffusion coefficients and partition coefficients were different under saturated and unsaturated conditions. Ong and Lion (1991a,b) reported that TCE sorption onto humic-coated alumina was enhanced at 80% relative humidity compared to either dry or aqueous phase; their proposed explanation for this behavior is that hydration of humic acid exposes internal surfaces. Later work by Cabbar (1999) used humic-clay complex pellets to investigate the sorption of trichloromethane and carbon tetrachloride. They found that at relative humidities less than 20% there was an appreciable decrease of the equilibrium sorption of these compounds when an increasing humic acid content was used. This was attributed to blockage of mineral pore sites by the humic acid.

The interaction between TCE and humic acids is significant for understanding the environmental fate of TCE in soil and water systems, as humic acids can influence the mobility and bioavailability of this compound.
